title: Consumers confused over financial advice: ASIC
text:
The corporate regulator has uncovered widespread confusion among consumers about the classifications of "general" and "personal" advice, which could become problematic for the major banks as they exit their wealth operations because attempts to sell products under a "general advice" label could be misleading to customers.

"Personal advice" takes into account a consumer’s personal circumstances, such as their financial situation, objectives and needs. In contrast, "general advice" is not tailored to any of the consumer’s personal circumstances. The classification is important because personal advice creates a legal obligation for the adviser to act in the customer's best interest and issue a statement of advice; if the advice is “general”, there is no such duty.

ASIC deputy chair Karen Chester at The Australian Financial Review Banking & Wealth Summit this week. She said on Thursday that "consumer confusion about what is personal and general advice needs to be addressed”. AFR

A new Australian Securities and Investments Commission report, titled “Financial advice: mind the gap” and released on Thursday, finds only 53 per cent of those surveyed could correctly identify a piece of "general" advice. Furthermore, nearly 40 per cent were unaware that advisers providing general advice are not required by law to act in their best interests.

Even though the major banks are getting out of personal advice, they may still seek to offer "general advice" in their branches, but ASIC is concerned that could confuse customers given such "advice" is often no more than a recommendation to buy a particular bank's products.

“This disturbing gap in understanding whether the advice they are getting is personal or not means many consumers are under the false premise their interests are being prioritised, when no such protection exists,” said ASIC deputy chair Karen Chester.
description: Major banks exiting personal advice have been put on notice the "general advice" label could be misleading to customers.
